results.title: Naming the federal capital of Australia: the ceremony
results.brief_description: Newsreel footage of the ceremonies surrounding the naming of Canberra on 12 March 1913 including scenes of Capital Hill, Andrew Fisher, Billy Hughes, the Light Horse Brigade and the laying of the various foundation stones. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Names of sin
results.creator_credit: Franciscan Communications Centre, Teleketics, Karl Holtsnider and Rolf Forsberg
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a nine-year-old girl Missy who is persuaded by her peers to throw a stone at an old lady. She later discovers that the old lady is dying and a personal awareness of having done an unloving act weighs heavily upon her. Her mother’s loving response to her torment and instinctive gestures of consolation even as she lets Missy know the seriousness of her action, frees Missy and she finds her own special way to express her sorrow. The dramatic tension traces the dynamics of the sacrament of Penance, as Missy experiences sorrow, guilt and the peace that comes with forgiveness.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Franciscan Communications Centre, Teleketics, Karl Holtsnider and Rolf Forsberg

results.title: Namekas: music in Lake Chambri
results.brief_description: Deals principally with the spiritual references that music has for the Lake Chambri people, featuring the sacred talking flutes that are played and seen only by men. Shows also songs of ceremonial and everyday nature, and other instruments, including the “talking” slit drums, panpipes, and a most unusual instrument in the form of a sago beetle. Produced with assistance from Australian Film Commission, Australia Council, Dept. Foreign Affairs and PNG National Cultural Council.

results.title: Nameday
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Eleni Arbus
results.brief_description: This short drama, shot in grainy colour, explores the conflict between a father and daughter within a contemporary Greek-Australian family. Estranged from her family for some time, a young women decides spontaneously to attend her father’s nameday party. When he rejects her, she determines to finally uncover the whole truth about a dark family secret that has haunted her since childhood. Told in a non-linear style, the film weaves together fragments of symbolic imagery and sound to evoke the memories that cause the daughter to suspect her father of murder. Each image sheds light on the previous, as the mysterious connection between the past and the present at the centre of the story is gradually revealed.

results.title: Name your poison (Captioned)
results.brief_description: The Tibaldi brothers add a light-hearted touch to the problem of alcohol. It covers reasons for drinking - boredom, rebellion, adult role models, peer pressure and the media - and looks at how some young people have developed a responsible attitude. An excellent discussion starter for young people about the use and abuse of alcohol.

results.brief_description: Through several episodes involving a lovers’ lane, baby sitting and a pickup, warns boys and girls against becoming victims of sexual criminals by pointing out the necessity of being aware of and avoiding possible dangers.

results.title: Namatjira the painter. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Ralph Foster and Stanley Hawes
results.brief_description: The story of Albert Namatjira, who once worked as a cook and camel-boy for the landscape painter Rex Batterbee. Namatjira became interested in painting and under Batterbee’s tuition, began to use watercolours to reproduce on canvas the Central Australian landscape. This vintage film, made at the height of Namatjira’s popularity shows the painter at work and discusses the influence of the environment on his beautiful original landscapes. Rich with illustrations of his work, this film is a tribute to the painter. Original ed. [307974].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian National Film Board, Ralph Foster and Stanley Hawes

results.title: Namatjira the painter (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Ralph Foster and Stanley Hawes
results.brief_description: Traces the life and artistic development of the Aboriginal painter, the late Albert Namatjira. His environment, his introduction to painting, his subsequent success with beautifully original landscapes and his influence on fellow Aborigines are recorded. [Rev. ed. 007430]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian National Film Board, Ralph Foster and Stanley Hawes

results.title: Naked states [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Juntos Films, Chaiken Films, Cinemax Reel Life, Jen Chaiken, David Nelson and Arlene Donnelly
results.brief_description: Spencer Tunick, internationally famous for taking public nude photographs ‘en masse’ has travelled the world photographing individuals and groups. “Naked states” is the documentary that helped make Tunick famous, chronicling his first major project, photographing people posing naked across 48 different states in America. This biographical documentary explores Tunick’s influences and motivations, commenting on the artistic process and the issue nudity. This rich documentary offers a sometimes intimate journey into the reasons why the subjects chose to pose naked. What is revealed, surprisingly, is not naked bodies but the breadth of difference of the people that make up our society and a generous spirit usually concealed. Contains nudity which may offend some viewers.
